docs.title: Deidentify Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the documentation for the deidentify.py script! This project helps anonymize and de-identify sensitive data using a YAML configuration file.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Hashing unique identifiers
  • Generating fake names, emails, and phone numbers
  • Anonymizing categorical data
  • Adjusting dates, semesters, and numeric columns

Get started by exploring the sections in the navigation bar!

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text: The config.yaml file customizes how data is de-identified. This file allows you to define how each column in your dataset should be processed.

docs.title: Example config.yaml
docs.text:
file_path: "./data/demo.csv"

# Column configurations
id_column: PIDM  # Unique identifier to hash
first_name_column: FIRST_NAME  # Optional first name column for de-identification
last_name_column: LAST_NAME  # Optional last name column for de-identification

# Year shift for dates
shift_years: 2  # Number of years to shift backward (set to 0 for no shift)

# Columns to be anonymized
categorical_columns:
  - MOST_RECENT_STUDENT_LEVEL
  - COLLEGE
  - MAJOR
  - ASTD_STATUS
  - SAP_STATUS

# Semester columns in YYYYMM format to shift
semester_columns:
  - COHORT
  - GRAD_TERM
  - MOST_RECENT_TERM_ENROLLED

# Optional columns to de-identify
email_column: EMAIL  # De-identify email column
phone_column: PHONE  # De-identify phone number column
student_id_column: PANTHERID  # Another ID column to hash

# Integer columns to adjust randomly by +/- 1
integer_columns:
  - HOURS_EARNED

# Float columns to adjust randomly by +/- 0.25
float_columns:
  - OUTSTANDING_FINANCIAL_BALANCE
  - INSTITUTIONAL_GPA
  - OVERALL_GPA

docs.title: file_path
docs.text:
• Description: Path to the input CSV file to be de-identified.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
file_path: "./data/demo.csv"

docs.title: id_column
docs.text:
• Description: Name of the column containing unique identifiers to hash.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
id_column: PIDM

docs.title: first_name_column (Optional)
docs.text:
• Description: Name of the column containing first names to de-identify by replacing with fake names.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
first_name_column: FIRST_NAME

docs.title: last_name_column (Optional)
docs.text:
• Description: Name of the column containing last names to de-identify by replacing with fake names.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
last_name_column: LAST_NAME

docs.title: shift_years
docs.text:
• Description: Number of years to shift date and semester columns backward. Use 0 for no shifting.
  • Type: Integer
  • Default: 0
  • Example:
shift_years: 2

docs.title: categorical_columns
docs.text:
• Description: List of columns containing categorical data to anonymize.
  • Type: List of Strings
  • Example:
categorical_columns:
    - MOST_RECENT_STUDENT_LEVEL
    - COLLEGE
    - MAJOR

docs.title: semester_columns
docs.text:
• Description: List of columns containing semester identifiers in the format YYYYMM to adjust.
  • Type: List of Strings
  • Example:
semester_columns:
- COHORT
- GRAD_TERM

docs.title: email_column (Optional)
docs.text:
• Description: Name of the column containing email addresses to replace with fake emails.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
email_column: EMAIL

docs.title: phone_column (Optional)
docs.text:
• Description: Name of the column containing phone numbers to replace with fake numbers.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
phone_column: PHONE

docs.title: student_id_column (Optional)
docs.text:
• Description: Name of the column containing student IDs to hash.
  • Type: String
  • Example:
student_id_column: PANTHERID

docs.title: integer_columns
docs.text:
• Description: List of columns containing integer values to randomly adjust by +/- 1.
  • Type: List of Strings
  • Example:
integer_columns:
- HOURS_EARNED

docs.title: float_columns
docs.text:
• Description: List of columns containing float values to randomly adjust by +/- 0.25.
  • Type: List of Strings
  • Example:
float_columns:
- OUTSTANDING_FINANCIAL_BALANCE
- INSTITUTIONAL_GPA
- OVERALL_GPA

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: This page demonstrates the functionality of the deidentify.py script using example input and output files.

docs.title: Copying Example Files
docs.text:
To copy the example files (demo.csv, demo_deidentified.csv, config.yaml, etc.) to a specific directory, use the copy_examples script:

copy_examples <destination_directory>

docs.title: Input File: demo.csv
docs.text:
The following is an example input CSV file (demo.csv). It contains sample student data, including personally identifiable information (PII) such as names, emails, and phone numbers.

PIDM,FIRST_NAME,LAST_NAME,MOST_RECENT_STUDENT_LEVEL,COLLEGE,MAJOR,ASTD_STATUS,SAP_STATUS,COHORT,GRAD_TERM,MOST_RECENT_TERM_ENROLLED,EMAIL,PHONE,PANTHERID,HOURS_EARNED,OUTSTANDING_FINANCIAL_BALANCE,INSTITUTIONAL_GPA,OVERALL_GPA
123456,John,Doe,Freshman,Arts,History,Active,Good,202101,202305,202401,john.doe@example.com,555-123-4567,890123,15,500.50,3.4,3.6
234567,Jane,Smith,Sophomore,Engineering,Computer Science,Active,Warning,202002,202406,202402,jane.smith@example.com,555-987-6543,123456,30,0.00,3.8,3.9
345678,Alice,Brown,Junior,Science,Biology,Inactive,Probation,202003,202405,202403,alice.brown@example.com,555-456-7890,789012,45,1200.75,2.5,2.6
456789,Bob,Johnson,Senior,Business,Marketing,Active,Good,202004,202404,202404,bob.johnson@example.com,555-321-6548,567890,60,200.25,3.2,3.3
567890,Mary,White,Freshman,Nursing,Nursing,Active,Good,202005,202303,202405,mary.white@example.com,555-789-1234,345678,12,800.10,4.0,3.9
678901,James,Davis,Senior,Law,Pre-Law,Inactive,Good,202006,202406,202406,james.davis@example.com,555-654-9876,234567,60,100.00,2.9,3.0

docs.title: Output File: demo_deidentified.csv
docs.text: After running the deidentify.py script on demo.csv, the output file (demo_deidentified.csv) contains de-identified data. The script replaces PII with hashed or fake values and anonymizes other sensitive columns.

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
PIDM,FIRST_NAME,LAST_NAME,MOST_RECENT_STUDENT_LEVEL,COLLEGE,MAJOR,ASTD_STATUS,SAP_STATUS,COHORT,GRAD_TERM,MOST_RECENT_TERM_ENROLLED,EMAIL,PHONE,PANTHERID,HOURS_EARNED,OUTSTANDING_FINANCIAL_BALANCE,INSTITUTIONAL_GPA,OVERALL_GPA
432019864722,Elizabeth,Swanson,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY01,202301,202505,202601,rebeccasanchez@example.org,8189337672,314032743269,16,500.6063399559087,3.203057793008891,3.6061180075905495
566881358185,Matthew,Moore,CATEGORY02,CATEGORY02,CATEGORY02,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY02,202202,202606,202602,trichard@example.net,(786)315-0721x7795,432019864722,29,-0.19413324184944286,3.9646301652937486,4.092289707854811
197119148968,Jamie,Johnson,CATEGORY03,CATEGORY03,CATEGORY03,CATEGORY02,CATEGORY03,202203,202605,202603,rita51@example.net,(951)427-9904x122,284893643451,46,1200.8592521436192,2.470694643359418,2.5655249945213976
234889864989,Sharon,Hughes,CATEGORY04,CATEGORY04,CATEGORY04,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY01,202204,202604,202604,andreamendoza@example.org,509-634-9063x814,849592214141,59,200.43628504721414,3.1988226475227637,3.2212546949824254
849592214141,Daniel,Allison,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY05,CATEGORY05,CATEGORY01,CATEGORY01,202205,202503,202605,becksusan@example.org,+1-266-489-8789x51883,197119148968,13,799.9231303982539,3.825228675431672,3.7616782781797102

docs.title: How to Use the Example Files
docs.text:
1. Confirm demo.csv is in the data directory. If not, use the copy_examples command outlined above.
  2. Use the following configuration in your config.yaml file:
file_path: "./data/demo.csv"
id_column: PIDM
first_name_column: FIRST_NAME
last_name_column: LAST_NAME
email_column: EMAIL
phone_column: PHONE
shift_years: 2
categorical_columns:
  - MOST_RECENT_STUDENT_LEVEL
  - COLLEGE
  - MAJOR
semester_columns:
  - COHORT
  - GRAD_TERM
  - MOST_RECENT_TERM_ENROLLED
integer_columns:
  - HOURS_EARNED
float_columns:
  - OUTSTANDING_FINANCIAL_BALANCE
  - INSTITUTIONAL_GPA
  - OVERALL_GPA

  1. Run the script: bash python deidentify.py --config config.yaml --input_dir ./data --input_file demo.csv

  2. The output file (demo_deidentified.csv) will be saved in the same directory.

docs.title: hash_id
docs.text:
Hash a unique identifier into a consistent numeric string.

Arguments:

  • identifier: The identifier to hash.

Returns:

A 12-digit hashed numeric string.

Example:

>>> hash_id("12345")
'098765432109'

docs.title: fake_name
docs.text:
Generate a fake first and last name.

Returns:

A dictionary with keys FN (first name) and LN (last name).

Example:

>>> fake_name()
{'FN': 'John', 'LN': 'Doe'}

docs.title: anonymize_categories
docs.text:
Anonymize a categorical column by mapping values to generic labels.

Arguments:

  • column (pd.Series): A Pandas Series containing the categorical data.

Returns:

A Pandas Series with the anonymized categories.

Example:

>>> anonymize_categories(pd.Series(['A', 'B', 'A']))
0    CATEGORY01
1    CATEGORY02
2    CATEGORY01
dtype: object

docs.title: shift_dates
docs.text:
Shift a date backward by a specified number of years.

Arguments:

  • date (str): The date string to be shifted.
  • years (int): The number of years to subtract.

Returns:

The adjusted date string, or the original value if invalid.

Example:

>>> shift_dates("2024-01-01", 2)
'2022-01-01'

docs.title: shift_semesters
docs.text:
Shift a semester identifier (YYYYMM) by a specified number of years.

Arguments:

  • semester (str or int): The semester identifier to be adjusted.
  • years (int): The number of years to add to or subtract from the semester.

Returns:

The adjusted semester identifier, or the original value if invalid.

Example:

>>> shift_semesters("202401", -2)
'202201'

docs.title: shift_integer_column
docs.text:
Randomly adjust an integer value by -1, 0, or +1.

Arguments:

  • value (int or float): The value to adjust.
  • mean (float): The mean of the column (not used in the current implementation).

Returns:

The adjusted integer value, or the original value if invalid.

Example:

>>> shift_integer_column(5, 4.5)
6

docs.title: shift_float_column
docs.text:
Randomly adjust a float value by a small amount (-0.25 to +0.25).

Arguments:

  • value (float): The value to adjust.
  • mean (float): The mean of the column (not used in the current implementation).

Returns:

The adjusted float value, or the original value if invalid.

Example:

>>> shift_float_column(3.5, 3.6)
3.3

docs.title: generate_fake_email
docs.text:
Generate a fake email address.

Returns:

A fake email address.

Example:

>>> generate_fake_email()
'john.doe@example.com'

docs.title: generate_fake_phone
docs.text:
Generate a fake phone number.

Returns:

A fake phone number.

Example:

>>> generate_fake_phone()
'(555) 123-4567'

docs.title: Setup Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to set up your environment to run the deidentify.py script using various installation methods.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure you have the following installed on your system:

  • Conda: Install Miniconda or Anaconda (Download Conda).
  • Git (optional): For cloning the repository if hosted on a platform like GitHub.

docs.title: 1. Install Using Conda and the deidentify-env.yaml File
View the deidentify-env.yaml File
docs.text:
The deidentify-env.yaml file specifies the required dependencies for the deidentify package:

# deidentify-env.yaml

name: deidentify
channels:
  - defaults
  - conda-forge
dependencies:
  - python=3.10
  - pandas
  - pyyaml
  - faker
  - pip
  - pip:
      - mkdocs
      - mkdocs-material

docs.title: Create the Conda Environment
docs.text:
Run the following command to create the environment:

conda env create -f deidentify-env.yaml

This will: - Create a Conda environment named deidentify. - Install Python 3.10, the required dependencies, and the pip-installed packages (mkdocs and mkdocs-material).

docs.title: Activate the Environment
docs.text:
Activate the environment with:

conda activate deidentify

You are now ready to run the deidentify.py script.

docs.title: 2. Install the Package Remotely from GitHub
docs.text: Follow these steps to install the package directly from GitHub:

docs.title: Create a Conda Environment
docs.text:
1. Create a Conda environment named deidentify with Python 3.10:
conda create -n deidentify python=3.10
  1. Activate the Conda environment:
conda activate deidentify

docs.title: Install the Package from GitHub
docs.text:
Install the package using pip:

pip install git+https://github.com/GSU-Analytics/deidentify.git

Verify the installation:

pip list

docs.title: 3. Local Installation (Clone the Repository)
docs.text: If you want to work with the package locally, follow these steps:

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/GSU-Analytics/deidentify.git
cd deidentify

docs.title: Install Locally Using pip
docs.text:
Install the package and dependencies with pip:

pip install .

docs.title: Alternatively, Use Conda
docs.text:
You can also use the deidentify-env.yaml file to create a Conda environment:

  1. Create the environment:
conda env create -f deidentify-env.yaml
  1. Activate the environment:
conda activate deidentify

docs.title: Running the Script
docs.text:
After installation, run the deidentify.py script using the following command:

python deidentify.py --config config.yaml --input_dir ./data --input_file demo.csv
  • Replace config.yaml, ./data, and demo.csv with the appropriate paths for your project.

docs.title: Copying Example Files
docs.text:
To copy the example files (demo.csv, demo_deidentified.csv, config.yaml, etc.) to a specific directory, use the copy_examples script:

copy_examples <destination_directory>

Replace <destination_directory> with the path to your desired location.

docs.title: Deactivating the Environment
docs.text:
When you're done working, deactivate the Conda environment with:

conda deactivate

docs.title: Updating the Environment
docs.text:
If new dependencies are added to the deidentify-env.yaml file, update your environment with:

conda env update -f deidentify-env.yaml --prune

docs.title: Using the Script
docs.text:
To run the deidentify.py script:

python deidentify.py --config config.yaml --input_dir ./data --input_file demo.csv

docs.title: Required Arguments
docs.text:
• --config: Path to the YAML configuration file.
  • --input_dir: Directory containing the input CSV file.
  • --input_file: Name of the input CSV file.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: python deidentify.py --config config.yaml --input_dir ./data --input_file demo.csv

docs.title: Using MkDocs
docs.text: This environment also includes MkDocs for generating and managing documentation.

docs.title: Preview Documentation
docs.text:
To preview your documentation locally, run:

mkdocs serve

Open your browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1:8000/ to view the documentation.

docs.title: Build Static Files
docs.text:
To generate static HTML files for deployment:

mkdocs build

The static files will be available in the site/ directory.
